Chat with an OpenAI model

Source: R/provider-openai.R
chat_openai.Rd

OpenAI provides a number of chat-based models, mostly under the ChatGPT brand. Note that a ChatGPT Plus membership does not grant access to the API. You will need to sign up for a developer account (and pay for it) at the developer platform.

Usage

chat_openai(
  system_prompt = NULL,
  base_url = "https://api.openai.com/v1",
  api_key = openai_key(),
  model = NULL,
  params = NULL,
  seed = lifecycle::deprecated(),
  api_args = list(),
  echo = c("none", "output", "all")
)

Arguments

system_prompt

A system prompt to set the behavior of the assistant.

base_url

The base URL to the endpoint; the default uses OpenAI.

api_key

API key to use for authentication.

You generally should not supply this directly, but instead set the OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable. The best place to set this is in .Renviron, which you can easily edit by calling usethis::edit_r_environ().

model

The model to use for the chat. The default, NULL, will pick a reasonable default, and tell you about. We strongly recommend explicitly choosing a model for all but the most casual use.

params

Common model parameters, usually created by params().

seed

Optional integer seed that ChatGPT uses to try and make output more reproducible.

api_args

Named list of arbitrary extra arguments appended to the body of every chat API call. Combined with the body object generated by ellmer with modifyList().

echo

One of the following options:

  • none: don't emit any output (default when running in a function).

  • text: echo text output as it streams in (default when running at the console).

  • all: echo all input and output.

Note this only affects the chat() method.

Value

A Chat object.

See also

Other chatbots: chat_anthropic(), chat_aws_bedrock(), chat_azure_openai(), chat_cloudflare(), chat_cortex_analyst(), chat_databricks(), chat_deepseek(), chat_github(), chat_google_gemini(), chat_groq(), chat_huggingface(), chat_mistral(), chat_ollama(), chat_openrouter(), chat_perplexity()

Examples

chat <- chat_openai()
#> Using model = "gpt-4o".
chat$chat("
  What is the difference between a tibble and a data frame?
  Answer with a bulleted list
")
#> - **Modernity**: 
#>   - **Tibble** is part of the tidyverse, a modern package in R 
#> designed for data science, whereas the **data frame** is the base R 
#> data structure.
#> 
#> - **Printing**:
#>   - **Tibble** prints only the top 10 rows and as many columns as fit 
#> on screen, making it more user-friendly for large datasets. In 
#> contrast, a **data frame** prints all columns and can output all rows,
#> which might overwhelm the console with large data.
#> 
#> - **Column types**:
#>   - **Tibble** retains the data types of columns and tasks more 
#> consistently without transforming data types implicitly, while a 
#> **data frame** may convert strings to factors by default unless 
#> specified otherwise.
#> 
#> - **Subsetting**:
#>   - **Tibble** will return an error if you access a column that does 
#> not exist, providing better error handling. A **data frame** returns 
#> `NULL` without a warning, potentially leading to debugging challenges.
#> 
#> - **Partial name matching**:
#>   - **Tibble** does not support partial name matching, which reduces 
#> accidental matches and ambiguity, whereas a **data frame** might.
#> 
#> - **Self-descriptive**:
#>   - When printed, a **tibble** reports the data types of each column, 
#> offering immediate data insights. A **data frame** doesn't display 
#> this information unless specifically requested.
#> 
#> - **Data types in construction**:
#>   - When creating a **tibble**, the input is preserved as is. A **data
#> frame** might coerce column types unless you define them explicitly.
#> 
#> - **Row names**:
#>   - **Tibble** does not support row names, encouraging users to treat 
#> data consistently as tidy data. **Data frame** allows row names, which
#> can sometimes complicate data handling.
#> 
#> - **Performance**:
#>   - Some operations on a **tibble** might be slower than on a **data 
#> frame** because tibbles use additional checks designed for 
#> user-friendliness and safety.
#> 
#> Understanding these differences can help you decide which structure to
#> use for your specific needs and navigate data manipulation efficiently
#> in R.

chat$chat("Tell me three funny jokes about statisticians")
#> Sure, here are three light-hearted jokes about statisticians:
#> 
#> 1. Why don’t statisticians play hide and seek?
#>    - Because they always find themselves in the standard deviations.
#> 
#> 2. How many statisticians does it take to change a light bulb?
#>    - Just one, but it takes them a whole study to figure out how to do
#> it with 95% confidence.
#> 
#> 3. Why did the statistician drown while crossing a river?
#>    - He was assured the river had an average depth of three feet!
